These stats are important for my followers in the US to read. Our nationalism is drilled into us from such a young age that, while I am not blind to our shortcomings, some of it still shocked me. I am aware that the US is in far better shape than the countries we have personally imperialised through history. But in the current climate of this country I felt compelled to share this information. We are not the country we have been led to believe we are in Hollywood movies. The USA is one of the most unequal countries on the planet in terms of wealth distribution, with a huge gap between the rich and poor, and low social security benefits, and lack of universal healthcare. People in this country (and I find many of my international friends) are unaware of statistics and facts such as these. We have done a criminally good job of propagandizing life here. Prioritizing white life, as these issues impact minorities disproportionally. Then there’s the health care crisis. Right now 25% of US citizens are suffering from delays in healthcare because of skyrocketing costs. 30 million US Americans are without health insurance. Although black women make up less than 7% of the US population, they represent about 10% of all missing persons cases. The Black and Missing Foundation estimates the total number of disappeared black women and girls at 64,000 in 2019. Our government has BEEN corrupt. But Trump’s administration has disregarded democratic norms, as loyalists are promoted, Trump pardons allies, domestic spending is redirected over congressional objection, and police use near lethal force on citizens. Nearly 40 percent of non-elderly adults struggle to meet basic needs such as food, health care, housing, and utilities. Just 6 countries rank above the US in rate of homeless population. 1.4 million Americans will spend time in a shelter in a given year. About 200,000 more are unaccounted unsheltered. More than 47 million Americans have filed jobless claims since March. For Black men, the lifetime risk of dying at the hands of police was 1 in 1,000. Black people make up 13% of the population but almost 30% of police shootings. Shootings. Not other deaths included in that statistic, such as... knees... Across the US infant mortality rates were up to 200 percent higher than in Austria, Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland. Black babies are affected the most. We have a terrible maternal mortality rate. There are about 37 deaths per 100,000 births in the USA compared to about 9 per 100,000 in the UK and Germany. Black women are 4 times more likely to die during childbirth in the US. 54% of black maternal deaths are preventable. For starters, we are not guaranteed clean drinking water. More than 60 million Americans are exposed to unsafe drinking water every year. Sincerely, Human Being with a Decade Long Bipolar Diagnosis.

If you wanna think someone is an asshole, go ahead. Lots of people with mental illnesses are great. Lots of them are assholes. Because they are people. With nuanced personalities. But making jokes specifically targeted towards bipolar hurts more than the 1 person ur angry with.
you can hate someone’s actions or opinions without contributing to stigma that damages an entire community of sometimes vulnerable people all for a couple of laughs.

A lot of people you know probably have bipolar disorder and you aren’t aware of it. Taking this opportunity to make offensive remarks and villify people with mental illnesses is really not the way to go...this is the exact triggering shit that causes people to keep quiet about it

No jokes right now. I have dedicated my career to offering education and insight about bipolar disorder and I’m so disturbed by what I’m seeing. Personal opinions about someone aside, a manic episode isnt a joke. If you can’t offer understanding or sympathy, offer your silence.

Felt like reposting that thread with more accurate and realistic verbiage. These stats are important for my followers in the US to read. Our nationalism is drilled into us from such a young age that, while I am not blind to our shortcomings, some of it still shocked me.

I am aware that the US is in far better shape than the countries we have personally imperialised through history. But in the current climate of this country I felt compelled to share this information. We are not the country we have been led to believe we are in Hollywood movies.

The USA is one of the most unequal countries on the planet in terms of wealth distribution, with a huge gap between the rich and poor, and low social security benefits, and lack of universal healthcare.

People in this country (and I find many of my international friends) are unaware of statistics and facts such as these. We have done a criminally good job of propagandizing life here. Prioritizing white life, as these issues impact minorities disproportionally.
Then there’s the health care crisis. Right now 25% of US citizens are suffering from delays in healthcare because of skyrocketing costs. 30 million US Americans are without health insurance.

Although black women make up less than 7% of the US population, they represent about 10% of all missing persons cases. The Black and Missing Foundation estimates the total number of disappeared black women and girls at 64,000 in 2019.

Our government has BEEN corrupt. But Trump’s administration has disregarded democratic norms, as loyalists are promoted, Trump pardons allies, domestic spending is redirected over congressional objection, and police use near lethal force on citizens.
Nearly 40 percent of non-elderly adults struggle to meet basic needs such as food, health care, housing, and utilities.
Just 6 countries rank above the US in rate of homeless population. 1.4 million Americans will spend time in a shelter in a given year. About 200,000 more are unaccounted unsheltered.
More than 47 million Americans have filed jobless claims since March.

For Black men, the lifetime risk of dying at the hands of police was 1 in 1,000. Black people make up 13% of the population but almost 30% of police shootings. Shootings. Not other deaths included in that statistic, such as... knees...
Across the US infant mortality rates were up to 200 percent higher than in Austria, Denmark, Finland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland. Black babies are affected the most.

We have a terrible maternal mortality rate. There are about 37 deaths per 100,000 births in the USA compared to about 9 per 100,000 in the UK and Germany. Black women are 4 times more likely to die during childbirth in the US. 54% of black maternal deaths are preventable.
For starters, we are not guaranteed clean drinking water. More than 60 million Americans are exposed to unsafe drinking water every year.

The USA generates a tremendous amount of media that propagandizes “The American Dream.” Here are some statistics about the USA that may surprise some people who defend it as “the greatest country in the world”:
RT @Blklivesmatter: Until today, you could be fired for being LGBTQ in 26 states in America. The Supreme Court has ruled 6-3, not anymore.…
RT @westonpagano: Living in America means calling the police could kill someone and calling an ambulance could bankrupt someone.
I am truly sorry if I offended you!

Thread gone. Only meant to educate my US followers on how our perception of the US is propagandized. I understand there are countries who are suffering beyond our understanding as a direct result of US imperialism. But Americans don’t realize how bad the statistics stack up here.

I know this isn’t an epiphany, and it seems simple and reductive if you’re reading this on a good day. But it’s an experience that always seems to throw me off balance and make my brain go ????? and I just felt like tweeting about it.
When heterosexuality is socially perceived as a “default”, you find yourself correcting people and reminding those who have still internalized this “default”.

Crazy how you think you just “come out” and then that’s it. It’s done. You’re out + everything is all good. When in actuality you’re coming out time and time again for your whole life. I remind others of this often when they come to me for advice. but it’s easy to forget, myself.
